commentBody: Sheesh. 20 minutes faster than my average. At first blush it looked like it was going to be a bit of a slog with the series of long across clues in the top right and bottom left, but it flowed well and ended up being a relatively easy solve (personally).

Loved the last clue. LOL!
Not a toughy, but a goody.

Obliterated my Friday record (by a full minute). 8:28. Would have been 7:45 except it took me 45 seconds to find a mistake at the end. The mistake. Had sAPS instead of TAPS. Of course, saps would have worked just fine, but obviously ssony isn't a thing...

I agree with Deb when she writes: 
   "I found many ways into Mr. Johnson‚Äôs puzzle and think it would be a good transition for those who want to push forward from the midweek puzzles."
Not far off my fastest Friday ever.

Wednesday is not named after the Norse god Odin but his Anglo-Saxon analogue, Woden. That's why "Wednesday" begins with W not O. The seven-day week with named days originated in the eastern Mediterranean, was adopted by the Romans, and then spread northward through Germania. It is documented in Rome in the first century, in England in the early 8th century, and is not documented in Scandinavia until ca. 1200 AD. Pagan Scandinavians had a five-day week whose only named day was the fifth (Bath Day, the name for Saturday in all modern Scandinavian languages). The seven-day week followed the Catholic church to Scandinavia.

Not through any fault of the puzzle, this one took me longer than usual, but I attribute that to two things:  1) I've developed a nasty cold, which is making me a bit sluggish, and 2) I had a typo near the bottom of the grid that took me a bit of time to locate.  

Anyway, I wanted to casually mention that I've hit a rather recursive number today; it's Day #3333 of my streak.  That's slightly more than nine years.  It's been a long time, but unless something happened I never heard about, David Connell is still ahead of me by about two months.

To everybody struggling to put a weeklong streak together, remember that I was there at one point (although no one was keeping track of streaks then), but with enough experience, you can get to the "when, not if" (I solve the puzzle) stage of puzzle solving.

At that point, you just have to make sure you don't forget to do the puzzle.  Since I'm not inclined to be watching TV at 10 pm, I can usually do the puzzle as soon as it hits.  But even when I can't, I still do it before going to bed.  Even if that's at 2 a.m.  (I find it helps relax me, as the main reason for not being able to do it earlier usually is that I was driving.)

It was weird when we were in Europe, because I had to switch to solving upon waking up.  Which will happen again in April, when we go to Morocco.  (Not in Europe, but same time zone.)

Anyway, happy solving to everyone!

Voting ends at 11:59 pm Friday, January 31, for the final round of the 2024 Puzzle of the Year awards, a/k/a the Griddies. We (me, John Ezra and Cat Lady Margaret) plan to announce the winners on Sunday, February 2. You can find the ballot at https://form.jotform.com/250186385916162. Again, puzzles are divided into four categories: Early Week (Monday‚ÄìWednesday), Thursday, Themeless (Friday and Saturday) and Sunday. There are five finalists in each category and you may vote for one puzzle in each category. Thanks to everyone who's voted so far.

It took me a bit to puzzle out the NE and the SW.  I was pleased to get the clue about the skier right as I know very little about skiing.  My self congratulations were a tad hasty, however, as I misspelled his name (Mayer instead of MAIER).  To further complicate matters I put in rout instead of ROMP, which was only half  wrong.   Figuring out MYRA magically unlocked the section, and helped me see the error of my ways.  I‚Äôve known several Miras, but the only MYRA of my acquaintance is Breckinridge.

This puzzle seemed challenging despite taking less than my Friday average, so that‚Äôs a winner in my book.

I was all set to put NONE.

But then Algeria saved me.

Now to think what the other eight are‚Ä¶

I appreciate your columns and sense of humour especially when solving frustrating puzzles. However, I think the picture on this article is insensitive in light of the tragic mid-air collision last night. So many lives lost. 

Surely, something could be substituted in the past twenty-four hours.

There were lots of nice clues in this one, but my favorite is 26D ALSO. It took me a few seconds after getting the answer to realize what the clue meant.

Of the answers, my favorite is 37D MAY I TRY. I'm better about not stepping in until someone asks for help than I used to be, but it's still difficult for me to watch someone struggle with something that I'm pretty sure I can handle easily.

But what I most enjoyed was learning about Adrian Johnson's crossword-solving friend Alexandra. I'm lucky enough to have made a similar friend through this comment section. 

Thanks, Mr. Johnson, for an entertaining puzzle.
Great puzzle! Did anyone else lose several minutes thinking it was DATED instead of DOZED?

Really enjoyed this, but frankly I thought my (wrong) first-pass guesses were way more funny. 

"He's taken!" --> SORRYGIRLS

One with sound judgment? --> PIANOTUNER

Mr. Johnson, I'd like to start out by saying that your ode to Alexandra was a beautiful thing to read. 
From your words, and your modesty in giving up your space to write about her, I can tell that the light you see in her is the same that is in you. 

That light - and lightness - was also in your puzzle.
I was taken aback by how an initially very scary-looking empty grid flowed so gently once I started. 

Every spanner was gettable, and every misdirect, a delight. 

So today there were two gifts - your words and your puzzle.
Thank you.

What made me smile was the proximity of amo to amo-ebas.
Ya just gotta love those one-celled critters.  Shades of biology class and loads of special memories are what make these  puzzles and community so very special.  I can disappear into a world of humor, cleverness, shared experiences and eliminate the awful din outside.  Thanks to all who make that happen.

Happy Puzzling - :>)
Lovely tribute to your friend Alexandra. Terrific puzzle‚Äînice way to end an insane day. Thank you.

This was the puzzle we needed on such a somber day:  comforting, engaging, and unstressful, with the extra commentary about the richness of friendship and the value of encouragement. 

The puzzle was not a difficult solve, but neither was it at all boring. Thank you, Adrian.  Alexandria is as lucky as you are to have such a steadfast friend.

I was somehow on the same wavelength as the constructor and solved it within 20minutes! Got all the long ones almost immediately, what a satisfying solve! Was stuck for a while as I thought it was a clever play for tAOISTS to be on the PATH.... to somewhere I guess, but on a second check I realised MAIER makes more phonetic sense as a last name and MAOISTS were far more likely to lead a revolution

Breezed through until the SW corner.  I didn‚Äôt know MAIER and I forgot about ADAM DeVine.  

I wanted to put pubGAMES instead of BARGAMES but the clue lacked any Briticism (a recently learned term). 

Peaceful puzzle that was a balm for my current state of agitation.

Haven‚Äôt done the puzzle. Haven‚Äôt read the column. Haven‚Äôt felt much like Games are even the right thing to be doing right now. Don‚Äôt know what is. 

Let‚Äôs not pretend all this is ok, because it‚Äôs not.
It was indeed easy but very enjoyable. Would have had my Friday record if I hadn't stuck with CAN instead of MAY on 37D.
Delightful and engaging crossword with a truly beautiful sentiment behind it. Bravo !

I‚Äôm the type of gal that likes a theme ‚Äî especially if it has a juicy rebus element. But this was a fun Friday, even if it was themeless! It took a couple circles around but steadily came together in patches. Got stuck for a few minutes in the NW corner, but once I finally realized 24A was not in fact ‚ÄúDATED‚Äù it was on to victory

Completed this while watching the Fire Aid concerts benefitting my beloved home state. Despite that, I was just a few minutes over my best time for a Friday. I must have been on the same wavelength as Adrian! I really enjoyed it, so thank you.

That was quite fun, with a lot of witty clues. The one I did not like was "Cat's scan? MICE" - I see what the constructor or editor was trying to do, but IMO it's too much of a stretch (rather than fun wordplay).

Over here most job fair attendees are first year students: last (third or fifth) year students probably attend, too, sometimes (I doubt there are *many* of them there, though), but since they've been working for several years already  and have careers and some INS, their job searches are usually more sophisticated. Most students study for free here - the right to free education including university level is enshrined in the Constitution. However, the best universities are located in big cities where the cost of living is high, so most students simply need to work to afford accomodation and food. The schools offer student housing at cost, but the number of spots is limited, and most students rent rooms on the market. Fee rent whole apartments as that is simply too expensive.
I haven't started the puzzle yet, so haven't read any comments or Wordplay. I just looked at 1D. I thought the answer might start with T and end with P, but I guess not.
19A. I must be missing something. The clue is awkwardly worded.  But Angola?

Having MANGO and AYO both crossing MAY I TRY was absolutely brutal for me, at least as clued. I originally had CAN I TRY, which left me with CANGO and ANO, both of which sounded plausible as somebody who doesn't know anything about Hinduism or actors from The Bear.

This went so smoothly at first that I felt like one of the cool kid solvers, but the SW got me stuck for a while. Not dAreWE, not ROut, too many blanks ‚Ä¶ but then trying ROMP opened it up, and still gave a new personal best at just over half my average time. Hooray!

Ah, Fridays.

so often we start with a numb, 59D
and then the walls come tumbling down

Strands Thread.  Spoilers after the View All Replies button please:


Strands #334
‚ÄúBaby talk‚Äù
üü°üîµüîµüîµ
üîµüîµüîµüîµ
üîµ

Needed the spanner to get things going.

Here I thought I was getting much better at Friday puzzles, only to find out everyone thought it was an easy one! Oh, well. I still got the confidence boost that Deb alluded to, and that‚Äôs nothing to SNEEZE at. 

What a lovely tribute to Alexandra. I‚Äôm sure it made her heart soar, because it definitely touched mine.

Funny I know lots of Jews who had palestinian passports back when such an entity actually existed (not as a state but as a geographical territory). In fact, prior to 1948, people known as Palestinians were primarily Jews since the concept of a "palestinian Arab" didn't exist.

Very enjoyable this morning, one of my swiftest. The crossers were extremely helpful to me, so the basketball solution and the purifying filters  just  appeared, but I did reveal MYRA and MAIER. The name Myra would never have occurred to me.

Anything to do with airports I try TSA, and anything to do with students is SNR.

Lovely jubbly!

That was fun.

 I struggled a bit,  however,  with the contractions.  They seemed to fit,  but I didn't think they were un answers unless there was some indicator.  Is that common? 

Just curious.  I haven't regularly done crosswords for years,  so maybe this is a newer phenomenon?

An enjoyable Friday puzzle. Not all that easy for me, of course, and had to cheat a bit in a couple of places, but just had a good time working things out. More than a few really clever clues. I'm not going to summarize my puzzle finds any more. I'll just provide a link for anyone who cares to go take a look. Today's was a Thursday from February 20, 2014 by Zhouquin Burnikel and Don Gagliardo. Here's the link: https://xwordinfo.com/Crossword?date=2/20/2014&g=11&d=D I'm done. ...
Nice variety of entries with some clever clueing.  Like others, I also enjoyed reading about Alexandra .
Well I fell in love with BLANKSTARE on the first pass, which made the SW corner a challenge.

First; my thoughts are with all affected by the horrific accident yesterday. Not helped by ridiculous comments from certain people.

A nice breezy puzzle, slightly chewy in the bottom left corner for me that needed a second coffee to push through. 
I find the idea of ingesting 18A quite scary in these troubled times, or is that just me?

What a lovely ode to Adrian‚Äôs mentor. She must be very proud of you. How lucky you are to have such a guiding light in your life.

@Steve L.
Thanks for your ONEON explanation yesterday. The time difference means I often pick up responses the next morning. The game is still clear as mud to me, but thanks for trying.

Crossword Revolution D10:  ‚ÄúAll of our lights inevitably go out, so act on the time you have with integrity, humor and humility.‚Äù  (See Constructor Note).

Plus, HUMOR/MARRIED MAN

A Word to Husbands (Ogden Nash)

To keep your marriage brimming
With love in the loving cup,
Whenever you‚Äôre wrong, admit it;
Whenever you‚Äôre right, shut up.

A Crosswords Saved the Day ‚Ñ¢ production.  TGIF!
My first choice for 1D was our current pres....

Yikes!

Apparently, that was my fastest Friday ever.
By far.

Really, truly enjoyed it, but
I would love a bunch more‚Ä¶crunch.

Yeah, I said it. A bunch more crunch.

Was able to use my Monday solve-pattern 
for the entire solve!
Pretty doggone sure that‚Äôs a first.

Guessing many like me were just crucivibing 
like crazy with the constructor, and if there
was anything to even look up I missed it!

Only nit? 
I wish this took three times longer! It was lovely + fun.
Funly.

Happy Funly Friday folks!

This might be a Lewis-y overreading, but I enjoyed the symmetrical placement of the the entertainment media-related RADIO DRAMA, AUDIOPHILE, RAP BATTLE, and CAMERA CREW. A [crooner] is hardly the way I would describe: https://youtube.com/watch?v=i_G_0vgEYJg (Not being content to restrict herself to the Alpine, Ms. Schneider travels on to the Iberian and the Gallic.) Oh G.d, to get that sound of my ear, here's a trio of genuine crooners: https://youtube.com/watch?v=q32Qlu981k0

Friday record for me. It did seem 'easy' for a Friday but I know better than to complain about that ! Also, I didn't even clock 'wanders' as meaning someone with a wand, but 3 letter word with any aviation reference in the clue and my brain autofills TSA (I also figured wanders might mean someone who wanders around, not that I'm even sure TSA staff wander around the airport terminal)

Thank you Mr. Johnson for a memorable puzzle and for your kind words regarding your friend, Alexandra. Friends must be cherished as they are often too few and gone too soon. 

It‚Äôs been an odd week with solving times. On Wednesday, my solve time was one minute slower than my average. Today, it was nine minutes faster than my average, only 25 seconds slower than my PB. Regardless, I‚Äôll take it all as a win for keeping my brain nimble.

Enjoy your Friday!

Adrian, your puzzle made my brain smile, and then I came here and read your notes, filled with love and wisdom, which made my heart smile warmly and deeply.  And here I sit in a puddle of feel-good.  Thank you!
Beautiful puzzle. Thank you.

For much of the puzzle I felt like I had taken a raft of SMART PILLS, but in the SW, I was reduced to chipping away ‚Äì slowing my breath and waiting for revelation.  It came, in dribs, and that‚Äôs just the kind of work my brain hungers for.  So, in the box today, the joy of ‚ÄúWhee!‚Äù mixed with the love of labor.  Sweet.

Along the way, gifts.  A terrific misdirecting clue ‚Äì [It‚Äôs followed by an extra point] for ALSO ‚Äì an answer that has appeared hundreds of times In Crosslandia, but never clued like this.  Also, the spark from freshness ‚Äì there are four stacks, totaling 12 answers, and 11 of them have appeared in the Times puzzle but four times or less.  Wow! My two favorite answers are debuts: A BET IS A BET and EMPTY STARE.

And afterward, a scan showing hardly a whiff of junk in this low-word-count puzzle (68), evidence of Adrian‚Äôs skill and persistence.

Joy, respect, and a host of goodies all rolled into one box.  Thank you for this gem, Adrian!
We‚Äôve been doing NYT crosswords every day together for the last few years. Today we hit a streak of 1000! Thanks to the setter for a great crossword.

In reference to 23A EIN this has been discussed many times over the years but I thought I‚Äôd bring it up again. The clue quote is from JFK‚Äôs famous speech during the Berlin Crisis of 1963 when he proclaimed solidarity with West Germany. The problem is that in German one would say ‚ÄúIch bin Berliner,‚Äù not ‚Äúein Berliner.‚Äù A Berliner is actually a kind of pastry so it sounded a little strange to some Germans.
Smooth solve until all I could do was sit and STARE at the EMPTY SW block until Mary's cousin MYRA broke the ice.  (Thanks girls!).

Serious question. Have Fri (and Sat) puzzles become much easier over the years, by design? Feels like I can cruise through the newer offers with relative ease. But when I go back to archives (for example, 2018 or earlier), some seem next to impossible, without loads of lookups. Just me?

ROut instead of ROMP gave me fits for a long time.

The last letter that I entered was the final "P" of THATS A WRAP, so I was smiling when the music played.

Fun puzzle for sure, but way too easy for Friday.
Cmon Deb & co, challenge us!

That was a surprising romp until I hit the SW corner. And I don't think it is because I am a divorced man. 

I completed 3/4s of the puzzle in about 15 minutes and then spent another 15 on the SW corner.

I doubt I have gotten that much better in the past month or so. I am betting a lot of comments mention that this was an easy Friday.

Yikes. Three American spellings to work around today.
Similar experience to many---a ROMP followed by a long hang up in the SW.  Couldn't see AMOEBAS for the longest time. And kept seeing MAIA/Maia instead of MARY/Myra!

Had no idea why the TSA were "wanders" (or indeed what the initials stand for), but they keep coming up in airport contexts, so in they went.
Usual work-around for unknown people's names---I knew I'd seen AYO here before, but of course had forgotten her immediately. But SO much better than yesterday's personal train-wreck. 
Enjoyed it.

That feeling of panic... when only AMO, LEO and EIN were on my grid.  (Rule of thumb: start with lowest hanging fruit, right?)  

I did love NINE, having tried a few times--in "A my name is Anna and I sell Apples..."--to come up with "A" countries, NOT continents, unable to get past four or five but knew it was surely more; so it had to be nine. (Antigua, Andorra, Angola, sadly fallen beneath my radar.)

Ultimately when the letters started to fall in place, though, it was like the end of a game of online solitaire, faster and faster.  Was that too easy?  Not until the critical mass was reached, for me anyway. Phew. "Ich bin frei" ... for Saturday!

Fun! Even a 48D.
Got a laugh from 6D. How old do you have to be to remember those ads? (You don't have to answer, @Deb Amien.)
I count only 5 proper names, none of which I 
knew but  all were pretty easy from crosses. Definitely will try to remember AYO since it's likely to be back.
Was quite approachable until I got stuck in the SW for several minutes. A very nice and enjoyable challenge.
One of those that seemed impossible at first and then with continual effort was solved before I knew it. Really enjoyed this one.

First day this week that I came in well below average. And I took a couple breaks but didn‚Äôt even consume any snacks.

The center squares were the last to fall for me. But my hairstyle knowledge helped me get through that little rough patch.
Mr. Johnson's puzzle was a bit easier for me than most Fridays after I "wandered" into the TSA line. Now I want to meet his friend Alexandra!

Just came in to praise Wanders Around a Terminal.  If we're stuck with both the agency itself and its TLA long term residency in crosswordese, this was by far the cleverest way to present it.

The whole puzzle was well constructed and fun.  Maybe too easy for Friday.  Great job.


____________________
Jesse Goldberg 8/28/2024 for Puzzle of the Decade
(emu filler)

Like many others, I had struggled with the SW corner.  But I also got stuck in the NE corner for a while.  For 24A, I had put in DatED, then changed it to DaZED when I realized the answer to 15D wasn't referring to some kind of rites.  I finally changed 24A to DOZED when I realized the public relations pro wasn't some kind of aCTOR, but instead was a kind of DOCTOR.

I think it's kind of neat though that all three of my guesses for 24A all work for the clue (but of course, only the last one worked for the crossing words).

Fun puzzle today, and I really enjoyed working out my mistakes and eventually getting to the end.

Did anyone else get stuck in the NW corner? I had DATED for 24A, but of course, couldn‚Äôt solve it with that. I was shocked I hadn‚Äôt needed any lookups to that point, but finally started checking my answers and alas, 24A was wrong. [Sigh]

I loved Adrian‚Äôs constructor comments. I, too, have been befriending older women in my life and have found them to be treasures of wisdom. What a wonderful tribute to your friend!

Ugh! ODIN is incorrect!

"Monday's Child"

Monday's child is fair of face,
Tuesday's child is full of grace.
Wednesday's child is full of woe,
Thursday's child has far to go.
Friday's child is loving and giving,
Saturday's child works hard for a living.
But the child that is born on Sabbath day,
Is bonny and blithe, good and gay.

And that is how Wednesday Addams got her name.

Apologies if Fact Boy already pointed this out.

A fun puzzle, not too difficult for a Friday. I solved in 6 minutes under my average. Today was one of those days where I happened to recognize many of the more obscure crosses at first glance, and I'm thankful that the constructor kept proper nouns and pop trivia to a minimum, those are my downfall usually.
With both RATS and MICE, this puzzle needed PEST control. Also DEER, if you have a garden. They're always munching on mom's hydrangeas.

Had a decent time, but SW was brutal. Here's my complaint: you have three name clues going down across a big stack and an excessively coy cat clue. That is some Naticking, if you ask me.

A Pitch Perfect actor (never saw it), Herman Maier (a FORMER Austrian skier?) and the elusive Mary/Myra trick.

Brutal.
Easy but fun. Finished 3 minutes off my record but well below my average

Solid but very gentle Friday puzzle. Solved it in unaided in fifteen minutes, which is about half my typical Friday solve time. Another example of the "Long stacks make puzzles *easier* to solve" phenomenon.

Time to see if others agree.
Some say easy, but any puzzle with this much white space automatically qualifies for end of the week.  That‚Äôs what I call an ‚Äòempty stare‚Äô.

So much fun. The SW had me stumped for a long while. 
Naticks ? I DONT BUY IT 
I had vale for DUCT tears

I love when things click

ohhhhhh... Wand-ers!

lovely friday puzzle :)
At the end, I had "STONY " for 1 Down, and was told something was still wrong.  I couldn't find anything so I asked to reveal the puzzle. You corrected STONY   to  STONY.

Excellent clues, as noted in the title of today's column.

 I had a problem with the request after a failure clue. My first entry was Can I Try. I mean why couldn't  the Hindu God of Fruits be Cango?

 But after filling all the squares in I got that  "something amiss" warning and wasted a good ten minutes scanning the grid before finally realizing that Mango was a better choice than Cango and May was a suitable replacement for Can.

Et voila!

Man I flew through 2/3rds of this one and had an entirely blank SW corner. I can‚Äôt even say what opened it up for me. I truly had to peck my way through it lol. At one point I even tried LIAMNEESON for [He‚Äôs Taken] even though I had some crosses I was confident in already that made that not make sense lol!!!
For "Animal resting place", I had SEMETARY at first which I think is more clever than BARNYARD to be honest.

This grid was very intimidating with all that open space, it was slow going at first.

As I filled in the knowns the unknowns became clearer, and the puzzle flowed like a gentle river. I filled in the last letter, certain that I was on the constructor's wavelength.

No happy music.

I scanned through the puzzle like a cat looking for mice, but everything seemed correct. Where could my error be?

Hmmm... this name looks funny, I should Google it. Yup, turns out it was the MAOISTS, not the Taoists, who were revolutionaries (and "Taier" is not a name).

üòÑ
I thought this one was fairly easy for a Friday. In fact, I beat my average time by ten minutes on my way to achieving my best Friday time ever. All while eating lunch!
I liked the intensity level for a Friday!   Did surprisingly well but got hung up on VALET and MANGO in the center.
16 min below my average time today, now THATS A WRAP .. fun puzzle

Started this on Thursday evening and got through all but the SW.  Completely stumped.  Decided to put it aside and then came back to it this morning, and finished that section in less than 2 minutes.  The ‚Äúcome back to it later‚Äù tactic works pretty much every time for me!   Amazing. 

My time was under my average but that‚Äôs nothing to boast about.  Fun puzzle, no lookups, and got the music on first attempt.
I liked this one! Challenging but doable start to our solving weekend.
Thank you, Adrian, for a fun, smooth solve, and for the beautiful tribute to your friend Alexandra!

Having gone into the SW corner with only 41D and 38D filled, I have to agree with the others about it being a bit trivia-heavy. Easy puzzle became tough.

37D was a good clue, though I didn't realize it meant "... following *someone else's* failed attempts".  On the other hand, even after reading this article, 46D's clue does not make sense to me; I know "scan" (noun) to mean "the process of searching" and "some documentation of a search"  but never "that which is sought after" as this puzzle claims. I could think of a dozen difficult but better clues for that one.
Beat my average by 21%.  It took my a while to crack the 10 x 4 block in the SW because it took me awhile to give up on blankSTARE.  Once I did, the rest came pretty quickly.

I wanted ALOOF for 1D, so I obviously got off to a poor start; this shows that starting at the top is just counter-productive!  So I went down to the bottom....where 35D was a sad reminder of the recent tragedy.
I scold with TSK and TUT!  (BAD! Would be if I had a dog.)
Have never heard A BET IS A BET.  But then, I don't gamble.
Just a lot of clunky entries with this one RADiO DRAMA!  (Yeah, in the 50's, likely before you were born, Adrian..)  
BAR GAMES.  
Wanted WALk, not ROMP.
Cat's scan? Leads to MICE?  Srsly?  A lot of folks have MICE and cats to control them nowadays??
Robt Frost thought HUMOR was cowardly?  Oh, yeah?
BANGS are not "a hairstyle," just a feature--a small part of a style.

Klunk clunnk thud skkkkrrrreeeeech  ....the sound of the clues and entries landing and dragging their fingernails over the puzzle page....
Sorry.  I guess I'm not feeling cheerful even though I got the puzzle.  Just so ODD!

Fun fact: A Berliner is a German doughnut or pastry that's made from sweet yeast dough and fried. It's typically filled with jam or vanilla cream and covered in powdered sugar, icing, or granulated sugar. 

How embarrassing for Kennedy.

Not quite the embarrassment that his brother's son has brought to the family and the nation.
Kudos to those who found it easy!  Not me.  I had only six entries before throwing in the towel in favor of Easy Mode.  And two of those were wrong!  I had to admire the clever clueing, though.
As someone who has participated in rap battles. I approved of this puzzle. *mic drop*

I have never heard , read or spoken a noun " wanders ".
A slang term I suppose.... a bit daffy

Very nice puzzle! Not a total ROMP but a nice brisk stroll around the block. It went smoothly for me except the SW corner. I'm not sure how I eked that area out when for the longest time I only had AMOEBAS and GARNET, oh, and CANTWE. Suddenly, MAYITRY came to me and I chipped away at the rest. Very enjoyable with loads of clever clues. WANDERS! Ha! 

I also appreciate hearing about Alexandra and the sage advice offered. These are trying times and we need to see our guiding lights, and hopefully, become guiding lights to others. 

Cheers and peace to you all!
Both easy to swallow and quite chewy....good Friday fare. And that's a wrap.

Finished the puzzle but something was wrong! I had CANITRY instead of MAYITRY, which led to CANGO instead of MANGO (I was thinking.... could be someone's name??) and ANO instead of AYO (a name I didn't know). Frustrating! Good puzzle otherwise - pretty fast for a Friday!
great puzzle until you get to the SE corner where you find 8 proper nouns, several of them crossing, which really nuked the enjoyment of the puzzle.

I had a lot of empty space at the bottom that refused to fill itself in, despite my pleas. I finally surrendered and looked up the "Pitch Perfect" actor's name, and things eventually began popping into place. So, a little tough for me, but not a tragedy. Thanks for the fun!
20 minutes slower than average! üò≠

RATS? MICE? I'm getting the heebie-jeebies. 
TOBEHONEST I hadn't heard of SMARTPILLS. 
I had a moment when I thought Hermann MAIER might be a 3rd skiing Mahre brother. 
I also considered "amoebae".
But here we are Friday evening, my daughter's coming down on  the train. Baked my banana layer cake with dark chocolate frosting. And tomorrow, Gypsy on Broadway. 
Cheers!

I agree with Deb. It wasn‚Äôt at all easy, but definitely doable over time. Got started over breakfast and made some good progress, then off for a morning volunteering, then finished it with lunch. We have been watching The Bear, so I knew AYO Edibiri. She‚Äôs a wonderful actress, and the rest of the cast is excellent too. I did look up The Queen  of Salsa though. It was a fun Friday challenge.  Thanks, Adrian Johnson üòä

I can finally say 4A about completing a Friday without hints or support! The bottom left corner had me stumped for a while with IAMDUBIOUS and BLANKSTARE for 52A and 56A. Realizing the shade of red I was looking for wasn't MAROON unlocked it for me. Great fun all around.
Can anyone explain why VALET is ‚Äúa short driver?‚Äù Is it a golf term I‚Äôm missing?  TIA.
I'm astonished that I could finish this in 21' with only one clues help ! First time for me on a Friday!  Thank you!

It‚Äôs fascinating to see the variance in people‚Äôs responses to puzzles. Sometime I get crushed by a puzzle, am convinced it was unfair and impossible due to some variety of naticks, only to come here and see people talking about what a breeze it was, record times, etc.

I usually keep quiet in those situations. üòÇ

Today, on the other hand, I arrive to see many people discussing how chewy and difficult it was. Since I‚Äôm commenting you can imagine my experience. More or less tied my record Friday time and was 70% below my average. 

Funny how the accumulation of our life experience and knowledge, along with perhaps our cognitive and emotional state at the time, translates to such different experiences. And nice to get a little confidence boost today.

Is nine countries correct? I count ten.

Albania, Algeria, Andorra, Angola, Antigua and Barbuda, Argentina, Armenia, Australia, Austria, and Aruba.
Loved this one - possibly just suited to my knowledge set but by miles the fastest I‚Äôve ever managed a Friday, and no hints needed - makes me feel like I‚Äôm getting better üòÇ
Fun puzzle, if a bit on the breezy side. I‚Äôm mostly here to comment about Mr Johnson‚Äôs lovely tribute to his friend Alexandra. What a touching story about friendship and human connection.

As a person of Indian origin I found the clue about the king of fruits very odd.  I‚Äôm sure there are non-Hindus in India (or elsewhere) who also hold that fruit in the same high regard.   While I‚Äôll be the first to admit that relishing a perfectly ripened specimen can be akin to a religious experience, I don‚Äôt believe that it‚Äôs limited to any one particular faith.
Not sure if I'd consider BANGS a hairstyle - more so a feature of some haircuts. That's my nitpicky two cents!

‚ÄúMice‚Äù doesn‚Äôt work for ‚ÄúCat‚Äôs scan?‚Äù A scan is a search, and besides, most of the time, cats are not seeing mice.  I love the clue‚Äôs clever punctuation and pun, but if the answer must be ‚Äúmice‚Äù, how about Cat catch, Cat‚Äôs pawed or etc. That‚Äôs for your next edition. 

And animals don‚Äôt rest in the barnyard where manure is dropped, but nearby in a barn, creating ft, hutch or etc. 

Overall delighted by your whole puzzle, especially Nine, TSA, Myra, DDay and more. Thanks!

what a nice wednesday-thursday-friday combination--all fresh and fun puzzles with just a hint of challenge. and some great cluing too.

fingers crossed that saturday keeps the streak going! it's actually ice cream for breakfast day tomorrow, and that definitely deserves a really fun and delicious solve!

Loved this puzzle. I go to xword stats now to see how hard they‚Äôre rated. So I had EMPTY Style for 
‚Äúlistless look‚Äù before EMPTY STARE and Mary before MYRA. üòÇ Fun one.

I completed the entire NW and SE corners on the first pass, about 5 minutes. After that, it took some breaks and coming back to it again to get those "oh, hello!" moments that @Lewis described so eloquently yesterday. Sometimes, you just need a break and the clue hits you a different way. A lot of fresh fill, clever wordplay, and minimal proper names made this a very fun puzzle. Overall, I record Friday of 17 min with no lookups, so I am quite pleased with myself.

I enjoyed much of this puzzle. The EMPTYSTARE, however, was quite disappointing, as I couldn't believe that someone would choose to use AMOEBAS when amoebae is available and obviously the superior plural.

About halfway through I had a feeling I just might finish this one.  And I did!!  Only my first or second ever Friday completion with no hints.  Honestly it feels good to finish a Friday after 15  years of solving.  I started at 35 and could do about 15 Monday clues and now all this.   Humbled.  Grateful.  Good puzzle with some very clever clues.  I liked Valet, Nine and  Camera Crew.  ‚úåüèº
p.s. thanks Deb for always encouraging us to not be so afraid of Fridays.  They‚Äôre slowly becoming my dark horse favorite.

One of these days I‚Äôll learn that seniors is shortened to SRS not SNS. It‚Äôs amazing how often I fill a clue in as SNS then because the middle letters not working with a crossing assume that it‚Äôs the wrong answer and erase the whole thing.

Loved it. No gimmicks. Just a great relaxing puzzle to end a rather harrowing week. While I enjoy a challenge, it's also very nice to have a challenging puzzle without all the drama. Thank you for this one. Nice work Adrian Johnson.
A Friday record for me! I really enjoyed this puzzle. For me, it was a steady solve from top down, The last section was the SW, which I finished off in no time after a good night's sleep.

@Warren 
Thank you for the link. Well written, as always. Whether I'll be able to take his advice is another matter.

@Justin 

I get it completely. It's overwhelming. 

Still, we have to take care of ourselves, including doing things we enjoy, in order to help anyone else. 

The day after the election, I took off work. I stayed in my PJs. I did nothing. I watched too much news, cried a lot, ate comfort food, and kept demanding my husband explain how this happened... as if he possibly could. I needed that day, but I can't live there. None of us can.

Someone told me to not read all the things, not try to help everything but to sit with yourself for a bit and decide what are your top issues of concern in this seemingly out of control dumpster fire we're in. Focus on what you can control and how you can help with those one or two issues. 

To help others, we need to take care of ourselves as best we can. If puzzles provide some peace and sanity in an insane world, allow yourself that time to rejuvenate yourself. 

You are not alone, in any case!

@NH Arabs‚Ä¶bedouins‚Ä¶. There were other tribes there other than people who called themselves Arabs.

It was a British protectorate which it acquired in 1916 after the Ottoman Empire fell apart.

So conceptually they were Ottoman who had controlled the area for 700 years.

Of course each ethnic group in the area had its own history.  In the west we think of Iranians as Arabs‚Ä¶but they‚Äôre not, they‚Äôre Persians. Kurds aren‚Äôt Arabs either.   We tend to group everyone in the Mideast as Arabs.

Also‚Ä¶places like Saudi Arabia or Jordan and other countries weren‚Äôt countries there.  They were cede over to specific families to lead the new countries‚Ä¶.But they were all historical parts of other empires.

@NH 
Back in what day? Palestine was a province of the Roman Empire, but the inhabitants did not qualify for Roman citizenship. Before that, it was part of Syria. Simply calling them Arabs works just fine.

@Steve yep they one bothered me a little bit.  I don't think I've ever heard or seen the phrase with anything other than the contraction...

@Oikofuge 
The TSA is the Transportation Security Administration. It was created after 9/11 to make air travel safer.

Part of this involved metal detectors (now full-body scans). If you set off the metal detector, or if you were "randomly" selected, a TSA agent would hover a metal detector wand over you to make sure you weren't carrying a weapon. Hence "wanders."

The wand always went off over my ankles. No idea why. Maybe my ankles were replaced with robot ankles without my knowing.

@Katie 

Thanks.
I knew they delivered airport security in the USA, but have never heard their hand-held scanners called "wands", or someone wielding a wand called a "wander", so that wasn't so much lateral thinking for me as orthogonal thinking.
I just stuck in the initials in "pencil" and waited to see what happened with the crosses.

@Katie 
It‚Äôs always my rib cage, which makes them very nervous. It‚Äôs seems my surgical steel rib sections may not be ‚Äòsurgical steel‚Äô. I dread to think what old junk they put in there , but it‚Äôs been 30+ years with no obvious harm.

@Rich in Atlanta 

Yikes, what a way to make that kind of discovery! I hope that, like @Helen Wright's ribs, you've gotten along with "no obvious harm" from the metal bits that remain with you.

@G 

Yes, I have. Actually I had always assumed that they had removed it all. And then a few years ago I had an MRI done and they popped me out quickly and said - there's still a lot of metal up there. 

I was surprised. Not sure if it's having any long term effects or not, but I am having increasing memory problems in the past few years. 

..

Brian, It seems Aruba doesn't count. Status Aparte Aruba seceded from the Netherlands Antilles in 1986, a victory much fought for by political activist and local hero Betico Croes. In this process of ‚ÄúStatus Aparte,‚Äù Aruba obtained a separate status as an autonomous country in the Kingdom of the Netherlands. Initially, the plan for Aruba was to become fully independent. However, in 1990, Aruba decided to indefinitely postpone this plan, and in 1995, the petition for full independence was completely repealed. https://aruba.com/us/our-island/history-and-culture/history
